translated: Now, since the eye is large and composed of many substances, why is it not perceived by the sense organ? Because it lacks the distinctive form of a lamp. translated: To describe the nature of objects, he says: The definition of objects is the nature of objects. It is of four kinds. In what form? He says: Terrestrial, celestial, gastric, and igneous. This is a specific dissimilarity of the object, which is distinguished from the body and senses by the definition of the object. Among them, what exists on the ground is terrestrial. Otherwise, if the previous form were not abandoned, the object would not be cognized later just as it was before. And the transformation into the appearance of the object should be understood as belonging to this blue, to this yellow, etc., due to the restriction to each object. Otherwise, if there were no transformation into the appearance of the object, this restriction would not exist due to the non-distinction of the transformation. Thus, when the sense organs have transformed into the appearance of the object, the intellect also transforms into that appearance.

translated: By this, it is understood that the apparent fallacies are refuted by implication, for the purpose of avoiding them in one's own statement and for the purpose of pointing them out in the statements of others. translated: Now he shows whose action has arisen, which produces worldly existence, and how it ceases. For the ignorant one, who has false knowledge, Dharma and Adharma have arisen, which produce worldly existence. He says that from the predominant Dharma, which produces worldly existence, along with a little Adharma, there is a connection with the desired bodies, senses, objects, happiness, etc. What is their distinguishing feature? They are in accordance with the intention, in accordance with the action. In which places? In the worlds of Brahma, Indra, Prajapati, Pitris, Rishis, and human beings. Similarly, from the predominant Adharma, along with a little Dharma, there is a connection with the undesired bodies, senses, objects, suffering, etc. In which places? In the abodes of ghosts and animals. He concludes: Thus, from that characteristic of engagement, from Dharma along with Adharma, there is the continuity, the series, of worldly existence again and again in the gods, humans, animals, and hells.

translated: Having taught the origin of the world from the Dharma that is the cause of continuation, he now speaks of its cessation from the Dharma that is the cause of cessation, saying But from that which is done with knowledge as the basis. That which has knowledge as the basis is said to be so. What kind of [Dharma]? From that which has an unseen result. It is said to be so because it has a result that is not imagined in this way: May my body, senses, and objects be accomplished in this way, not in this way. From that, birth occurs in a pure family. For one who is born thus, the desire to know the means of removing suffering arises. How can one attain complete separation from the continuum of suffering? Thus, the desire to know leads to approaching a teacher. Having approached him, one learns the means of turning away from the continuum of suffering. From the knowledge of reality, one attains the highest good. Then, from the practice of the scriptures, the knowledge of the truth of the six categories arises. For one who has attained the knowledge of the six categories, the cessation of ignorance occurs. With its cessation, detachment arises. The cause of that is the knowledge of the truth of the six categories.

translated: Now, for the purpose of examining the definition of inherence, the section begins with of only those that are not produced simultaneously. The relation of only those that are not produced simultaneously, which are the supported and the supporter, is inherence. This definition has been explained. Now, he says, this relation is of those that are not produced simultaneously, namely, substance, quality, action, universal and particular. For the sake of showing the absence of restriction, it is said to be of cause and effect such as cloth etc. No, it is of those that are not cause and effect, such as the universal and its possessor. This restriction is that the relation of inherence is the state of being the supported and the supporter of those that are not produced simultaneously. And this relation called inherence is the cause of the cognition this in that. And the aphorism is: That inherence of cause and effect, which is the basis of the cognition 'this in that'. Here means the substratum. This means the superstratum. Without the relation of those two, the cognition this in that does not occur. And because it is of those that are not all-pervading, this suspected restriction is refuted.
